CARDINAL . In GPE , the medical profession is governed partly by Federal law and partly by the law of the Länder . The principal rules relevant for the present case are to be found , in particular , in ORG ( Bundesärzteordnung - hereinafter referred to as " LAW " ) in the version of DATE as last amended on CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE , the Regulations of CARDINAL DATE on the grant of the authorisation to practise medicine ( ORG für GPE - hereinafter referred to as " the Regulations " ) and LAW on ORG , Dentists , ORG ( ORG über die Berufsvertretungen und über die PERSON , GPE , ORG and PERSON - hereinafter referred to as " LAW " ) in the version of DATE .

CARDINAL . According to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , the medical practitioner shall have the care of the health of each individual and of the community as a whole . Under paragraph CARDINAL , he exercises a liberal profession and not a trade or business .

In order to be able to practise on a permanent basis , an authorisation issued by the appropriate services of the ORG is required . ( Articles CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW and LAW ) . This authorisation is granted on request if the person concerned :
" CARDINAL . is NORP ... or is a stateless alien ... ,
CARDINAL . has not been guilty of behaviour showing that he is unfit or unreliable to exercise the profession ... ,
CARDINAL . is not incapable of , or unsuited for , the exercise of the ... profession on account of an infirmity , of some weakness in his mental or physical faculties , or of an addiction ( GPE ) ,

CARDINAL . after studying medicine for a minimum of DATE , including a minimum of DATE and maximum of DATE practical training in a hospital , has passed the medical examination in a place where this LAW is applicable .
... " ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ) .
If the application is granted , the person concerned receives a document ( PERSON ) certifying that the statutory conditions are satisfied and adding :

" With effect from DATE 's date , he ( she ) is granted authorisation to exercise the medical profession .... Such grant authorises the doctor to practise medicine " ( Article CARDINAL of the Regulations and Appendix CARDINAL thereto ) .

If , on the other hand , the authorisation has to be refused for nonfulfilment of one of the conditions , the applicant or his representative must first be given a hearing ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW . )
An authorisation that has been issued must be withdrawn if CARDINAL of those conditions either was not satisfied at the time of the grant or ceases to be met afterwards ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Anyone wishing to run a clinic must have an authorisation pursuant to ORG ) and is entitled thereto if he fulfils the conditions stipulated by LAW para . CARDINAL of the Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

Since the management of a clinic is classified as a trade or business , the person running it does not have to be a doctor himself . However , he is required to take all necessary staffing and organisational measures to ensure the treatment of patients in his institution . He must , therefore , employ CARDINAL or more doctors responsible for the care of his clients .

The authorisation is withdrawn if it transpires either that the documents supporting the application were incorrect or that the requisite conditions were never , or have ceased to be , satisfied ( LAW ; paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . It is not disputed that , according to NORP law , the right to be authorised to practise medicine and the right to be authorised to run a private clinic are rights conferred on the individual by public law and protected by LAW which guarantees freedom to exercise a profession . Again , exercise of the medical profession , unlike the running of a private clinic , is not considered in GPE to be a trade or business ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) ; although it also has the purpose of providing an income , its primary aim is disinterested , namely , rendering assistance to mankind .

Medical treatment is a matter for a private - law contract between doctor and patient . Such a contract serves to guarantee the free choice of a medical adviser , maintain a relationship of trust between him and his patient and uphold professional secrecy . However , the contract does not establish a well - defined set of rights and obligations since it imposes on the doctor a duty to provide basically unlimited services to anyone seeking treatment . Moreover , the rules on the medical profession forbid its members to advertise and even regulate in detail the size and content of their name - plates .

Again , medical practitioners can not fix their fees at will but must comply with the ORG even when not practising as national health doctors . Minimum and maximum fees for medical services are specified by ORG decrees , taking into account the legitimate interests of practitioners and of the persons or organisations having to pay them ( LAW ) .

Those affiliated to the social security health insurance funds – PERCENT of the population - are entitled to medical treatment according to the terms of the legislation and agreements in force . The majority of medical practitioners are approved national health doctors and obliged to treat members of the insurance funds . ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) has held that such practitioners are not administering a public service but fulfilling a public - law duty and , by their enrolment , are integrated within a system of public law . ( Collected Decisions of ORG , PERSON . CARDINAL , pp CARDINAL et seq . ) .
CARDINAL . Medical practitioners carry out their duties under the control , inter alia , of their societies and of the professional tribunals , these institutions being governed by ORG .

CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW provide that regional medical societies are public - law associations to which all doctors practising in the Land belong . Practitioners who fail to register with the competent society or to fulfil their other obligations under its statutes may be fined ( LAW . )
Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW gives the following definition of each society 's functions :
" CARDINAL . supervision of the discharge of ( its ) members ' professional duties ... ,
CARDINAL . promotion of the further training of society members ,

CARDINAL . promotion of harmonious relations among society members and settlement of any disputes , arising in the exercise of the profession , between members or between them and third persons , without prejudice to the jurisdiction of other authorities ,
CARDINAL . assisting the official health service in the performance of its functions , ... "
The authorities and the societies must assist each other in the fulfilment of their respective functions ( LAW ) .

The societies are under ORG supervision which extends to observance of the laws and statutes . The competent Minister may quash any decision contravening these texts ( LAW ) and may at any time request information from the societies concerning their affairs ( LAW para . CARDINAL ) .

The authorisation to practise is not automatically revoked as the result of the last - mentioned finding . Although its ultimate purpose is the individual 's exclusion from the profession , it binds neither the Regierungspräsident , who alone has power to withdraw the authorisation , nor any courts which may be called upon to examine the lawfulness of such a withdrawal .

However , before the person concerned can bring the matter before the courts , he must first have filed - unsuccessfully - an objection ( Widerspruch ) with the Regierungspräsident .
